options.name: -c
tip: First and second line of paragraph may have different indentations,
in which case the first line's indentation is preserved, and each subsequent line's indentation matches the second line.

options.name: -t
options.tip: Like -c, except that the first and second line of a paragraph *must* have different indentation or they are treated as separate paragraphs.

options.name: -m
tip: Attempt to detect and preserve mail headers in the input.
Be careful when combining this flag with -p.

options.name: -s
options.tip: Split lines only, do not reflow.

options.name: -u
-p
tip:
U: -p|--prefix <PREFIX>
Reformat only lines beginning with PREFIX, reattaching PREFIX to reformatted lines.
Unless -x is specified, leading whitespace will be ignored when matching PREFIX.

options.name: -P
tip:
U: -P|--skip-prefix <PSKIP>
Do not reformat lines beginning with PSKIP.
Unless -X is specified, leading whitespace will be ignored when matching PSKIP

options.name: -x
options.tip: PREFIX must match at the beginning of the line with no preceding whitespace.

options.name: -X
options.tip: PSKIP must match at the beginning of the line with no preceding whitespace.

options.name: -w
tip:
U: -w|--width <WIDTH>
Fill output lines up to a maximum of WIDTH columns, default 75.
This can be specified as a negative number in the first argument.

options.name: -g
tip:
U: -g|--goal <GOAL>
Goal width, default of 93% of WIDTH.
Must be less than or equal to WIDTH.

options.name: -q
options.tip: Break lines more quickly at the expense of a potentially more ragged appearance.

options.name: -T
tip:
U: -T|--tab-width <TABWIDTH>
Treat tabs as TABWIDTH spaces for determining line length, default 8.
Note that this is used only for calculating line lengths; tabs are preserved in the output.

description: Reformat paragraphs from input files (or stdin) to stdout.
